articles.headline: A DeVos System Allowed 12 Minutes to Decide Student Loan Forgiveness
articles.snippet: Education Dept. documents filed in federal court describe a process that denied 130,000 claims from borrowers who say schools misled them.
articles.abstract: Education Dept. documents filed in federal court describe a process that denied 130,000 claims from borrowers who say schools misled them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former Education Secretary Betsy DeVos made no secret of her disdain for a program intended to forgive the federal student loans of borrowers who were ripped off by schools that defrauded their students. She called it a “free money” giveaway, let hundreds of thousands of claims languish for years and slashed the amount of relief granted to some successful applicants to $0.

articles.headline: Confronting Violence Against Asians, Biden Says That ‘We Cannot Be Complicit’
articles.snippet: Vice President Kamala Harris joined the president in forcefully condemning the killings in Atlanta. “Racism is real in America, and it has always been,” she said.
articles.abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris joined the president in forcefully condemning the killings in Atlanta. “Racism is real in America, and it has always been,” she said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris traveled on Friday to Atlanta to express grief for the victims of a mass shooting that left eight people dead, six of them women of Asian descent, describing the tragedy as part of an increase in racially motivated violence and pledging to take action against hate and discrimination.

articles.headline: ‘All I Can Think About Is Her’: Families Grieve for Victims of Atlanta Attacks
articles.snippet: Among the eight people killed at Atlanta-area spas this week was a wife going for a massage with her husband, and immigrant mothers working long hours to support their children.
articles.abstract: Among the eight people killed at Atlanta-area spas this week was a wife going for a massage with her husband, and immigrant mothers working long hours to support their children.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — From early in the morning until late at night, Hyun Jung Grant was at work. She was a single mother with life’s unyielding obligations: two sons who needed college tuition, the rent on the home they all shared, the relentless drumbeat of bills.
articles.byline: By Juliana Kim, Corina Knoll and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Where Europe Went Wrong in Its Vaccine Rollout, and Why
articles.snippet: While Washington went into business with the drug companies, Europe was more fiscally conservative and trusted the free market.
articles.abstract: While Washington went into business with the drug companies, Europe was more fiscally conservative and trusted the free market.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The calls began in December, as the United States prepared to administer its first batches of Covid-19 vaccine. Even then, it was clear that the European Union was a few weeks behind, and its leaders wanted to know what they could learn from their American counterparts.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Selam Gebrekidan and Monika Pronczuk

articles.headline: There Is No Rung on the Ladder That Protects You From Hate
articles.snippet: Asian-Americans are reeling from the killings in Georgia and a rising number of attacks nationwide. Could confronting racism bring solidarity across their class divides?
articles.abstract: Asian-Americans are reeling from the killings in Georgia and a rising number of attacks nationwide. Could confronting racism bring solidarity across their class divides?
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: That Was Fast: Blowups With China and Russia in Biden’s First 60 Days
articles.snippet: It may look like the bad old days of the Cold War, but today’s bitter superpower competition is about technology, cyberconflict and influence operations.
articles.abstract: It may look like the bad old days of the Cold War, but today’s bitter superpower competition is about technology, cyberconflict and influence operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sixty days into his administration, President Biden got a taste this week of what the next four years may look like: a new era of bitter superpower competition, marked by perhaps the worst relationship Washington has had with Russia since the fall of the Berlin Wall, and with China since it opened diplomatic relations with the United States.

articles.headline: Atlanta Suspect’s Fixation on Sex Is Familiar Thorn for Evangelicals
articles.snippet: The man accused of killing eight people, including six women of Asian descent, blamed “sexual addiction,” a disputed term used in parts of evangelical culture.
articles.abstract: The man accused of killing eight people, including six women of Asian descent, blamed “sexual addiction,” a disputed term used in parts of evangelical culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: In City After City, Police Mishandled Black Lives Matter Protests
articles.snippet: Inquiries into law enforcement’s handling of the George Floyd protests last summer found insufficient training and militarized responses — a widespread failure in policing nationwide.
articles.abstract: Inquiries into law enforcement’s handling of the George Floyd protests last summer found insufficient training and militarized responses — a widespread failure in policing nationwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many long weeks last summer, protesters in American cities faced off against their own police forces in what proved to be, for major law enforcement agencies across the country, a startling display of violence and disarray.
articles.byline: By Kim Barker, Mike Baker and Ali Watkins

articles.headline: Access, Influence and Pardons: How a Set of Allies Shaped Trump’s Choices
articles.snippet: A loose collection of well-connected groups and individuals led by a pair of Orthodox Jewish organizations had striking success in winning clemency for white-collar criminals during the Trump presidency.
articles.abstract: A loose collection of well-connected groups and individuals led by a pair of Orthodox Jewish organizations had striking success in winning clemency for white-collar criminals during the Trump presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One hacked the computers of business rivals. One bribed doctors to win referrals for his nursing homes.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Recast as ‘Stimmies,’ Federal Relief Checks Drive a Stock Buying Spree
articles.snippet: The government set out to prop up the economy. It may also be propping up the market.
articles.abstract: The government set out to prop up the economy. It may also be propping up the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Abraham Sanchez knew exactly how he wanted to spend his stimulus check.

articles.headline: After Tony Hsieh’s Shocking Death, Zappos Looks to Move Forward
articles.snippet: Kedar Deshpande, who took over as C.E.O. in August, needs to lead the shoe seller out of the pandemic, while maintaining what his predecessor built.
articles.abstract: Kedar Deshpande, who took over as C.E.O. in August, needs to lead the shoe seller out of the pandemic, while maintaining what his predecessor built.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was never going to be easy to succeed Tony Hsieh, the celebrated chief executive of Zappos, who turned a tiny online shoe seller into a $1 billion behemoth through an obsessive focus on corporate culture and happy employees. But Kedar Deshpande took over at a particularly fraught time.

articles.headline: Rich Countries Signed Away a Chance to Vaccinate the World
articles.snippet: Despite warnings, American and European officials gave up leverage that could have guaranteed access for billions of people. That risks prolonging the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Despite warnings, American and European officials gave up leverage that could have guaranteed access for billions of people. That risks prolonging the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the coming days, a patent will finally be issued on a five-year-old invention, a feat of molecular engineering that is at the heart of at least five major Covid-19 vaccines. And the United States government will control that patent.
articles.byline: By Selam Gebrekidan and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Assaulting the Truth, Ron Johnson Helps Erode Confidence in Government
articles.snippet: Pushing false theories on the virus, the vaccine and the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Mr. Johnson, the Republican senator from Wisconsin, has absorbed his party’s transformation under Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: Pushing false theories on the virus, the vaccine and the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Mr. Johnson, the Republican senator from Wisconsin, has absorbed his party’s transformation under Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROOKFIELD, Wis. — Senator Ron Johnson incited widespread outrage when he said recently that he would have been more afraid of the rioters who rampaged the Capitol on Jan. 6 had they been members of Black Lives Matter and antifa.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Think Covid’s Messed Up Your Travel Plans? Try Getting Into China.
articles.snippet: To keep the virus out, Beijing has enacted some of the world’s toughest border controls. Lives have been upended, and business has been disrupted.
articles.abstract: To keep the virus out, Beijing has enacted some of the world’s toughest border controls. Lives have been upended, and business has been disrupted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leave your partner and children behind. Quarantine for up to a month. Get inoculated with a Covid-19 vaccine from China, if you can find one. And prepare yourself for an anal swab.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Postal Service Struggles to Speed Up Delivery, Compounding Its Troubles
articles.snippet: Months after the election highlighted the agency’s problems, delivery times are still falling short of its standards, and a plan to try to shore up its finances could further slow some mail.
articles.abstract: Months after the election highlighted the agency’s problems, delivery times are still falling short of its standards, and a plan to try to shore up its finances could further slow some mail.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — William Pietri, a software engineer in San Francisco, put careful thought into his Christmas box for his family in Michigan, jamming it with tastes from around the world and other gifts: Indonesian ginger candy, Mexican saladitos con chile, Korean honey butter almonds, a puzzle that was almost impossible to find.

articles.headline: He Redefined ‘Racist.’ Now He’s Trying to Build a Newsroom.
articles.snippet: The author Ibram Kendi and The Boston Globe are teaming up to cover racism, inspired by Boston’s 19th-century abolitionist newspapers.
articles.abstract: The author Ibram Kendi and The Boston Globe are teaming up to cover racism, inspired by Boston’s 19th-century abolitionist newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Ibram X. Kendi and Bina Venkataraman met last summer when their big Boston institutions, Boston University and The Boston Globe, were grappling with protests over racial justice.
